concept.title: Start and end touch points
concept.shortdesc: When you configure a path request, you must specify a start point or an end point for the path. You can also define both a start point and an end point.

conbody.p: A touch point is associated with an interaction, also called an event. For example, you might specify an event such as opening an email as the start touch point for a path. Or, you might specify a cart purchase as the end point of a path. If you define a start touch point, the path contains interactions that followed the start point. If you define an end touch point, the path contains interactions that led to the end touch point. If you define both a start point and an end point, the path contains interactions that occurred between the two points.
When you add a start or end touch point to your path request, you must specify the following criteria to define the touch point:

section.title: Event type
section.p: Event types vary according to channel, and they can be initiated by customers or by your company. Each event type contains attributes that define the event. For example, the Cart Purchase Item event can include attributes such as the product name and price. You can view the list of attributes, and other details about an event, when you define the touch point.

section.title: Filter criteria
section.p: You can limit the path results by filtering on any of the event attributes. For example, you can filter the Email Open event by message name or message ID.

section.title: Event date range
section.p: When you select an event as the start or end touch point of a path, you can limit results by specifying an event date range. The path results contain only events that occurred within the date range that you specify.
